metadata.sermon_start_end: In his penetrating book The End of the Christian Life, Todd Billings—who is living with incurable cancer—writes: One of my favorite parts of Sunday worship comes when I stand with the congregation and sing the Doxology. [...] As we are momentarily taken up out of ourselves in this world, how much more shall we all together be taken up into the dance of the blessed Three in One for ever and ever. Gloria in excelsis Deo!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The text fails Dekker's primary requirement of being an 'exposition of a specific Bible passage.' It is a thematic essay on doxology using a collage of verses (Revelation, Chronicles, Psalms, Hebrews, Mark). It lacks the 'starting point' of a singular pericope that says something found nowhere else.
quotes: The 'ascriptions' in 1 Chronicles were commonly used...
Revelation contains more references to glory than any other book...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one specific pericope (e.g., Revelation 7:9-12) and derive the entire sermon's movement from its unique linguistic and theological structure rather than using it as a proof-text for a general theme.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no formal exegesis. The preacher mentions 'ancient Israel' and 'the seer on the Isle of Patmos,' but these are historical generalizations rather than linguistic or contextual analysis of the Hebrew/Greek text. The theology of the biblical books remains on the surface.
quotes: An abiding concern in ancient Israel was that the glory of Yahweh would be upheld...
The vision of the seer on the Isle of Patmos is the most comprehensive...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Engage with the specific Greek/Hebrew nuances of a single text. Explain what 'glory' (kabod/doxa) meant specifically in the context of the chosen passage's historical crisis.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is present but tends toward the general or liturgical. It touches on 'diminishing church attendance' and 'greed and folly' regarding the environment, but remains somewhat abstract. It lacks the 'true truth' of concrete, situational specificity Dekker demands.
quotes: This can actually be felt by a worshiping congregation at times...
even the earth as we know it, in extremis as it is with our greed and folly...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move from 'the earth' or 'the congregation' to specific, contemporary manifestations of 'idols' that the doxology must dethrone in the hearer's current life.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: Because there is no sustained exposition of a single text, the interwovenness is replaced by a thematic flow. The hearer is not 'drawn into the text' but rather into a reflection on the concept of worship.
quotes: The season of Epiphany is designed for the purpose of doxology.
When we praise the glory of God, something of that glory is imparted to us.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Structure the sermon so that the contemporary application arises directly out of the unfolding of the biblical text's own logic.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon effectively addresses 'gratitude' (doxology) and touches on 'misery' (mortality, cancer, greed). However, the 'misery' is often framed as a biological or social fact rather than man's misery 'before God' (coram Deo).
quotes: Todd Billings—who is living with incurable cancer...
the very goal of the repentance for sin is not only personal deliverance...
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect by showing how the specific text judges the hearer's specific resistance to God's glory.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon mentions 'judgment' and 'being lost,' but the 'two ways' are not the driving force. The seriousness of the 'ultimate possibilities' is softened by a focus on the cosmic rebirth, though the inclusion of the spiritual 'My Lord, what a morning' adds a necessary note of gravity.
quotes: find their ultimate destiny—both for judgment and for redemption...
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Make the choice between the 'broad way' (idolatry/greed) and the 'narrow way' (doxology) more urgent and mutually exclusive.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: This is the strongest point. Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon emphasizes that glory is a gift and that Christ's cross is his glory. It avoids making worship a human achievement.
quotes: The season after Epiphany is designed to do just this: to build up... to the narrative of Jesus’ Passion...
the cross of Christ is his glory...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure that Christ is not just a 'theme' of the season but the specific 'salvation outside himself' that the text offers to the hearer.

8_depth_and_length.findings: The estimated duration is approximately 14-15 minutes. According to Dekker, a sermon under 20 minutes lacks the necessary 'breadth' for 'depth.' The text feels more like a concluding chapter or a short address than a full-scale sermon.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical depth and the concrete application to reach the 20-minute threshold required for substantive proclamation.

overall_assessment.summary: The text falls short of Dekker's definition of a sermon primarily because it is a thematic reflection rather than an exposition of a specific Bible passage. It lacks rigorous exegesis and fails to meet the 20-minute minimum for depth. However, it succeeds in maintaining a Christocentric focus and correctly identifies the movement of misery, redemption, and gratitude in the background.
strengths: Strong Christocentric telos, linking glory specifically to the Passion.
Adequate background use of the three parts (misery, redemption, gratitude).
Effective use of the 'two ways' through the inclusion of the apocalyptic spiritual.
weaknesses: Lack of a single, specific biblical pericope as the starting point.
Insufficient length to achieve the 'breadth' required for homiletical depth.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an edifying theological essay or a 'speech about the gospel,' but it is not a 'sermon' in the strict sense of Dekker's theses. It lacks the formal requirement of recreating a specific written Word into a new, current, proclamatory word through rigorous exposition.
